missionProperties.missionDescription: The emergency broadcast from the Rebel outpost on Indu led you and the other strike team, led by Princess Leia Organa, into an ambush. You managed to beat back the first wave of assailants before you had to flee the Lord of the Sith himself, Darth Vader. Now you are in your shuttle, racing desperately toward the location of Leia's last broadcast, hoping to find the other strike team still alive.
missionProperties.additionalMissionInfo: This tutorial will teach you the remaining rules and some intricacies after you finished the first two tutorials.

events.eventText:
Your shuttle speeds low over Indu, the canopy of the planet's beautiful forests a green blur below you.

It has been almost half an hour since your last contact with Leia Organa, and you can only hope that you will reach her in time. The location of her last transmission is beeping softly on the navigation computer, signalling the position of the Rebel outpost the Princess and the other strike team set out to investigate.

eventActions.tbText: You check the set course again, but there is nothing else you can do to speed up your journey. So you sit back in the cockpit and allow yourself a moment to breathe.

Welcome to the third tutorial for Imperial Commander. This tutorial aims to teach you the remaining rules not covered by the first and second tutorials. As before, refer to the Rules Reference Guide or the wiki documentation if you have any questions.

Place Gaarkhan's and Jyn Odan's Hero sheets in the play areas of their respective players, as well as their starting items (the cards from their Hero Class deck without an XP cost). Then, search Gaarkhan's Hero Class deck for the card Wookiee Loyalty and place it in Gaarkhan's play area, and search Jyn Odan's Hero Class deck for the card Smuggler's Luck and place it in Jyn's play area.

Just to do something, you search through the shuttle to see if there was any equipment left behind that might be useful to you. To your surprise, you actually find something: an armored coat as used by the Rebel soldiers, and a counterweight compatible with Gaarkhan's vibro-ax.

Search the Item card deck for the Item cards Combat Coat and Balanced Hilt. Item cards are divided into 3 tiers. The cards you are looking for are in the Tier I deck. Place the Combat Coat in Jyn's play area and the Balanced Hilt next to Gaarkhan's weapon.

In Imperial Assault, you can earn credits during missions that can be spent to buy items before the next mission. For the purpose of this tutorial, you get these items for free right now. The Combat Coat makes Jyn sturdier. It increases her Health by 2, and it allows her to convert 1 {F} (Evade) into 1 {G} (Block). For example, if she rolled a {F}, but the enemy rolled no {B} she needs to negate, she can simply convert it into a {G} to reduce incoming damage. This ability is always active, so she can use it for any attack targeting her. However, she cannot use it more than once per attack.

The Balanced Hilt is a modification. Modifications do not work on their own, but they can be attached to an item card with the matching icon. In this case, the Balanced Hilt is a {P} (melee) modification, so it can be attached to any {P} weapon, like Gaarkhan's vibro-ax. The orange slot at the bottom right of the vibro-ax's card shows how many modifications an Item can have. In this case, the vibro-ax can only carry 1 modification at a time, but that's enough for now. The Balanced Hilt can be used while attacking - anytime, even after rolling the dice - to add 1 {B} (Surge) to the results. It must be exhausted (turned 90° clockwise) for this, though, so Gaarkhan can only use it once per activation. Remember that all cards belonging to a hero ready again at the start of that hero's activation.

<color="yellow">Unless the Item card explicitly states otherwise, you cannot swap items with other heroes during a mission. However, at the start of each mission, all available items can be distributed between heroes freely.

There are some limitations, though. Each hero may only bring 2 Weapons, 1 Armor ({R}) and 3 Equipment ({S}) Item cards. Modifications do not count as weapons, despite their icons.</color>

You finally approach your destination and land the shuttle on a clearing near the position where the outpost has to be. Then you ready your weapons and head for the door.

<color="yellow">Place Jyn's miniature on the green highlighted space and Gaarkhan's miniature on the blue highlighted space.</color>
You exchange one last glance, then open the shuttle door, ready for anything. Behind the door lies the lush forest of Indu with more crumbling ruins.
Stormtroopers have already moved into position as they saw the shuttle landing. They raise their weapons and aim for the shuttle door.

The twilight of the forest makes it impossible to see what lies beyond this clearing as long as you have other things to worry about, but the outpost must be near. You can even see an old supply crate lying around, left behind by the Rebels.

translatedEntityProperties.theText: This looks like a crate the Rebels left behind, half overgrown by the forest.

eventActions.tbText:
"Drop your weapons!", the stormtrooper commander shouts, but you didn't come here to surrender. Gaarkhan snarls, grabs his ax, and rushes toward the Imperial soldiers with a roar.

<color="yellow">In normal missions, the Rebels get the first activation and can decide themselves who gets to activate. However, let's start with Gaarkhan.</color>

Heroes have special abilities that set them apart. They are often divided into active and passive abilities. Gaarkhan, for example, has the passive ability Rage: After an attack targeting you is resolved, if you suffered 3 or more {H}, you become Focused. This means that every time the Empire attacks Gaarkhan, they run the risk of enraging the Wookiee - never a good idea.

Focused is a condition. There are several conditions that can benefit or hinder a figure. "Beneficial" conditions are characterised by a green back, "harmful" conditions have a purple back. When a figure gains a condition, take the respective Condition card and place the condition token next to that figure or its Deployment card / Hero sheet. A figure can never gain a condition it already has. If a figure is Focused, the next time that figure attacks or performs an attribute test, it rolls 1 extra green die, then discards the Condition card. So if Gaarkhan is Focused, his next attack or attribute test will be much better.

Many abilities grant a figure a Special Action. Special actions are indicated by the {A} symbol preceding them. If a figure has access to a special action, the figure may spend 1 action per {A} symbol to perform that special action.

Gaarkhan has the special action Charge: {A}2{C}: Move a number of spaces up to your Speed. Then, you may perform an attack with a {P} weapon. By spending 1 action on his special action, Gaarkhan can both move up to 4 spaces and attack, effectively saving the action of having to run up to the stormtrooper. Also note that this action moves Gaarkhan spaces, so he does not need to spend movement points for it and can move through difficult terrain or hostile figures without additional movement point cost. However, this also means that he can't split the movement and save movement points for later with this action.

Most abilities have some sort of cost. In the case of "Charge", the cost is 1 action, but there is an additional cost. The text "2{C}" means that using this ability requires suffering 2 "strain". Strain is represented by the {C} tokens, which are placed on the hero sheet just like {H} tokens. A hero can suffer a maximum of strain up to the hero's Endurance rating. Heroes can never voluntarily suffer strain beyond their Endurance rating. This means that Gaarkhan can use "Charge" while he has suffered 0, 1, or 2 {C}, but not at 3 or 4 {C}, because using the ability would exceed his Endurance rating. However, some enemies or events may cause a hero to suffer {C} beyond the hero's Endurance rating. Any strain involuntarily suffered beyond that limit is converted to {H} (damage).

<color="yellow">So, to summarize: Gaarkhan can spend 1 action and suffer 2 {C} to use his special action "Charge", thus moving 4 spaces toward an enemy and attacking that enemy. He can only use this action once per activation, though.

Sounds good, doesn't it? Then attack those stormtroopers. Remember that the vibro-ax has the surge ability {B}: Cleave 1 {H}. This means that Gaarkan can spend a {B} rolled during the attack (or added by the Balanced Hilt) to have another enemy figure adjacent to him (other than the attacked target) suffer 1 {H}, so try to find a position where you can use that.

Once Gaarkhan has charged, he still has an action left, for example to attack a second time. When Gaarkhan has finished, start the next Imperial activation. Keep playing until the stormtroopers are defeated.</color>

events.eventText: You pry the crate open, and the lid crashes to the ground. Inside, you can see a few useful things. Opening a crate usually gives the hero who opened it a Supply card. Gather all Supply cards and remove the card Troop Data; this card is not used when using Imperial Commander. Then shuffle the cards and randomly draw 1 of the cards. The hero who opened the crate places this Supply item in the player's play area. Supply items do not carry over between missions. They are shuffled back into the deck after the mission ends, so make sure to use them.

eventActions.tbText:
Under the supplies, you find a medpac that still looks to be usable.

<color="yellow">Place 1 strain token somewhere in the Rebels' play area. This is a medpac. Medpacs are a shared resource, and all players have access to it. Players start each mission with 1 medpac and might find more by opening crates during missions. When you find a medpac, place another strain token in the play area. When you use a medpac, discard 1 of those strain token.

Just like supply cards, medpacs do not carry over between missions. They are a rare supply for the Rebel Alliance.</color>
<color="yellow">Claim the crate token. In a regular mission, you gain 50 credits for each claimed crate token at the end of the mission.</color>

translatedEntityProperties.theText: This looks like a crate the Rebels left behind, half overgrown by the forest.

eventActions.tbText: With so many sources for {C} and {H}, it might be necessary for heroes to heal occasionally. This is done with the final action not yet described: Resting. A hero can spend actions to perform a Rest. This means that the hero recovers strain equal to the hero's Endurance rating, discarding that number of {C} tokens from the hero sheet. A hero cannot recover more strain than the hero has {C} tokens.

When performing a Rest, a hero can decide to also use 1 of the available medpacs. If the hero does that, 1 medpac is discarded, and the hero also heals 5 {H}. And there's one last way to recover strain: When a hero attacks, the hero can decide to spend 1 {B} to recover 1 strain. The hero can only spend 1 {B} for this per attack.

Here's an overview over the available actions for heros: {-} Attack: Attack a hostile figure or token. {-} Move: Gain movement points equal to your speed. {-} Interact: Interact with an adjacent token. {-} Rest: Recover {C} equal to your Endurance rating, may use 1 available medpac to also recover 5 {H}. {-} Special: Use an available special action.
<color="yellow">Keep performing actions to rest the heroes until all hero activations are finished, then end the round.</color>

eventActions.shortText: Finish all activations, then end the round.

events.eventText: The last stormtrooper falls, and you lower your weapons and take a few deep breaths. You need to find the outpost, but first there may be something useful in the old supply crate. Crates can contain a variety of useful supply items that might help during a mission. Heroes can interact with crates to open them. Some crates may have special rules, but usually they simply contain supplies. Open the supply crate. Remember you need to be adjacent to a token and spend an action to interact with it.

translatedEntityProperties.theText:
This looks like a crate the Rebels left behind, half overgrown by the forest.

<color="yellow">A hero can interact with the crate to open it.</color>

events.eventText: The stormtroopers aim to return fire, but Jyn is faster, firing off shots at them. Not all abilities need to be used during a hero's activation. Some can be used outside of an activation. Such abilities use the term interrupt to signal that they happen during another figure's activation. Jyn Odan possesses the special ability Quick Draw: 2{C}: Use at the start of a hostile figure's activation. Interrupt to perform an attack with a PISTOL, targeting that figure. Limit once per round (twice if you have 2 activation tokens).

eventActions.tbText: When an enemy group activates, the Rebel players decide the order in which the figures of that group activate. At the start of an enemy figure's activation, if Jyn has line of sight to that figure, she can decide to fire a shot before they can act. She can only do this once per round, though (or twice if she has two activation tokens, which she has since there are only 2 heroes in this tutorial). Using Quick Draw requires Jyn to suffer 2{C}. She should have line of sight to at least 1 stormtrooper who is still alive, so she may suffer 2{C} to shoot first. If she manages to defeat the stormtrooper, that figure is removed from the map and its activation ends immediately. Proceed to the next stormtrooper, if there still is one. If it was the last figure of the group, end the group's activation and defeat the group after you close all windows.

<color="yellow">Abilities are not the only reason why a hero will voluntarily suffer strain. Up to twice per activation, a hero can decide to suffer 1{C} to gain 1 movement point.

With this, a hero could, for example, suffer 2{C}, gain 2 movement points, use them to get closer to an enemy, and still attack twice, because the hero didn't need to spend an action on movement.

A hero can only gain a maximum of 2 movement points per activation this way.

Finish the Stormtroopers' activation now, then play until all stormtroopers are defeated. (Perform activations and end rounds as needed.)</color>

events.eventText: With fresh eyes, you look around for a way to the outpost. You finally notice that there are small pathways leading away from the clearing. As you follow them, you find a way through the trees and toward a large section of the forest.

eventActions.tbText: At the far end, you can see the small Rebel outpost.

The door to the outpost is black with scorch marks. Shouts and the noise of battle echo through the woods, and the area in front of the outpost is swarming with Imperial soldiers. The Empire has erected a mobile gun station that is blasting the outpost door relentlessly.

The E-Web Engineer is a large figure. Any figure whose base is larger than 1 space is considered a large figure. When a large figure is deployed to a single space, place it on the map so that any one space of its base occupies the indicated space. You decide the specific positioning. Large figures have a few special rules attached to them.

<color="yellow">{-} When a large figure attacks, line of sight may be traced from any of the spaces it occupies. When a large figure is targeted by an attack, the figure performing the attack must target one of the spaces the large figure occupies.
{-} Large figures cannot move diagonally.
{-} A large figure may spend 1 movement point to rotate 90°. When doing this, the large figure must still occupy at least half of the spaces it occupied before the rotation. However, this is only necessary for figures with an asymmetrical base. The orientation does not play any role in determining the direction of movement or attack.
{-} Large figures are subject to all movement requirements for terrain and other figures, but they are subject to these requirements only once per movement point spent. For example, if an E-Web Engineer moves into two spaces containing Rebel figures, it must only spend one additional movement point instead of two.</color>
Near the blaster cannon, more stormtrooper are preparing to advance.

<color="yellow">When a group with multiple figures is deployed to a single space, place all figures as close as possible to that space. Usually, this means that 1 figure is placed on the indicated space itself, with the remaining figures adjacent to it. If the space is already occupied, place the figures as close as possible.</color>
The noise of the fight and the scent of blood and death has attracted a snarling creature from somewhere deep within the forests. It creeps closer, baring huge fangs.

The Nexu is a {W} (Mercenary) unit, so its deployment card has a green back. It is another large figure and subject to all rules for large figures. However, its Deployment card also shows that it is Mobile, so it can move into and occupy spaces with blocking or impassable terrain. Therefore, place the Nexu figure in the corner of the map, with one of its spaces on the blocking terrain. This is a valid position for the Nexu.

The Nexu also has a passive ability, Cunning. This means that, when it rolls a {F} while defending, it adds 1 {G} to the results. Always check the Deployment cards of unfamiliar groups to find out if they have any abilities you need to keep in mind.

One last notable thing about the Nexu is the keyword Bleed. There are multiple keywords, such as Bleed, Stun, Hide or Focus, that allow a figure to gain or inflict conditions with an attack. Harmful conditions, such as Bleeding or Stunned, are inflicted on the target of the attack. Beneficial conditions, such as Hidden or Focused, are gained by the figure itself. Most keywords are surge abilities, meaning that a figure must spend a {B} to gain or inflict that condition. Others, like the Nexu's Bleed, are not tied to a surge, so they are automatic with each attack. However: To apply a condition, an attack has to inflict at least 1 {H}. If the Nexu attacks and the attack does at least 1 {H}, the target becomes Bleeding. If the attack doesn't inflict any damage, the keyword has no effect. When a figure gains a condition, search the Condition deck for the card and place a condition token next to the figure or on its Deployment card / Hero sheet.

Note that the conditions Stunned and Bleeding on Imperial figures work differently from how they are described in the Rules Reference Guide when using Imperial Commander. Refer to the wiki documentation for details.

Some crates are scattered throughout the clearing, left behind when the Rebels hastily retreated into the outpost.

<color="yellow">Remember that you can open crates to gain Supply cards and find medpacs to heal. You don't have to wait until you have defeated all the enemies, you can always open a crate by interacting with it.</color>

eventActions.tbText: As you approach the clearing, Leia's voice comes in through your comlink, sounding strained. "I told you to get back to the Sundered Heart!", she grumbles, but her voice is soon overridden by the strike team's lieutenant. "We're glad you're here", he says. "Commander Organa is hurt, and we need the backup." "I can still fire a blaster", Leia protests in the background. "Thanks for the distraction. We're coming out there to support you. Troopers, prepare for breakout!" With the Imperials' attention on you, the door to the outpost suddenly slides open, revealing Alliance soldiers with their weapons drawn.

<color="yellow">The group just deployed is an Ally group, so grab the Rebel Trooper Deployment card. It's a Rebel card with a red back. Familiarize yourself with the Rebel Troopers' abilities.

Allies can be activated and spend two actions exactly like heroes. Only 1 action may be spent on an attack, though. The players decide when to activate an ally. However, an ally can only be activated once per round.

The players also decide the order in which the figures in an ally group activate.</color>

The Alliance soldiers start blasting the Imperials while you charge from the other side. Time to break the siege.

<color="yellow">Keep playing until all enemy groups are defeated.</color>

events.eventText: The last Alliance soldier falls to his knees. Now it's only you and Leia.

Clutching one hand to her bleeding side, Leia fires off a few shots with her blaster pistol.

{-} Choose any enemy figure on the map. That figure suffers 1 {H}.

The E-Web Engineer swivels his cannon to take aim. When you look at the E-Web Engineer's Deployment card, you can see that his Assault ability allows it to perform multiple attacks each activation. This means that the E-Web Engineer can resolve multiple {Q} instructions, which - combined with the large attack dice pool - makes it a very dangerous enemy.

The Nexu snarls and tenses his body for a mighty jump. The Nexu's Pounce instruction again involves moving spaces instead of spending movement points. This means that it is not subject to the movement restrictions of a large figure. The Nexu simply jumps to any space that is up to 6 spaces away from it. Place it in a way so that any space of its base is on the target space.

eventActions.tbText: In the Nexu's bonus effect, you might also happen upon the term exterior space. Exterior spaces are all spaces on a map that represent an outdoor space. On the current map, the shuttle and the outpost are interior spaces while all other spaces are exterior spaces.

events.eventText:
Finally the last enemy falls, and the remaining troops scatter.

Leia groans, still pressing her hand to her side, eyeing the forest warily.

"Thanks for coming to get us", she finally says. "I'm glad you escaped Vader, but we don't have much time. I'm sure he is hot on your heels. Our shuttle was shot down, but we can squeeze all the staff from this base into yours."

She gestures toward the outpost. Civilian staff and wounded soldiers are huddled in the back. Leia quickly gets them up, and the ones who can walk help those who can't. However, there are still more people here who are hurt.

eventActions.tbText: An unconscious soldier has been left behind.

<color="yellow">A hero can interact with the soldier to carry him, retrieving the token.</color>

<color="yellow">A hero can interact with the communication officer to carry her, retrieving the token.</color>

eventActions.tbText: Leia nods toward the two Alliance members. "We're gonna need your help. Can you take them to the shuttle?" In some missions, tokens can be retrieved. To retrieve a token, a hero needs to interact with it. Then that token is placed on the hero's Hero sheet to indicate that the hero is carrying it. The two Rebel mission tokens represent wounded Alliance members. The heroes can retrieve them by interacting with them. A hero can carry 1 mission token per activation token the hero possesses. When the hero is wounded, he drops the token in his current space. The hero (or a different hero) can interact with it to retrieve it again.

translatedEntityProperties.theText:
The shuttle is packed with the surviving Alliance personnel. Once everybody is on board, it is ready to start.

<color="yellow">When all surviving heroes are on the shuttle, and both Rebel mission tokens are carried, a hero can interact with the terminal to launch the shuttle and end the tutorial.</color>

events.eventText: The shuttle's engines roar to life. "Brace!", shouts Leia as the repulsor kicks in and lifts the vehicle into the air. There are a few screams from the survivors as shots hit the shuttle, but the deflector shields hold, and you activate the sublight drive and blast off into space. TIE fighters await you, and the silhouette of a star destroyer looms not far behind, but the X-wings launching from the Sundered Heart keep the TIEs at bay until you're safely aboard. Shrugging off any attempt at treating her wounds, Leia hurries to the bridge, accompanied by you. The X-wings return to the hangar bay, and before the star destroyer can reach your ship, you jump into hyperspace, and safety.

eventActions.tbText: When the Sundered Heart drops back into realspace, a beautiful, orange gas giant hangs in the black void of space. The ship sets course towards a small jungle moon orbiting the planet, and finally lands outside an ancient-looking pyramid that obviously serves as the Rebel base. As personnel and droids hurry toward you to take care of the wounded, Leia, looking relieved that you made it, beckons you to follow her. She takes you into the pyramid and to a tall human male with striking white hair and beard. "General Dodonna", she says. "These are the new recruits I told you about. They really stood their ground on Indu. We wouldn't have made it here if not for them." Dodonna examines you attentively, then nods. "This is high praise coming from Her Highness. She told us you discovered something about an Imperial weapons project. We need to debrief you, but for now, I think it's time to rest." He turns toward his aide. "Show them to their quarters", he says, before giving you one final look. "Welcome on Yavin IV."

This wraps up the final tutorial for Imperial Commander. You should know all the rules required to find your way around now, and hopefully even had some fun learning them. For details, refer to the Rules Reference Guide provided with the game, and the wiki documentation for Imperial Commander. When you're ready to go ahead, start the mission Aftermath from the core game, the first real Imperial Assault mission. The tutorials did not cover anything about campaign structure and progress. You can find all about that in the Learn to Play guide and the wiki documentation, or you can go ahead and read it at the end of this tutorial. This will not be interactive, though, just a help to guide you through the process.

events.eventText: The shadow of an Imperial lambda-class shuttle falls over the clearing, and Leia looks up, fear on her face. "That's him", she breathes. "We don't have much time."
Darth Vader will arrive in &Vader Arrives& rounds.
Darth Vader will arrive in &Vader Arrives& rounds.
Darth Vader will arrive in &Vader Arrives& rounds.

The sound of a mechanical breathing apparatus is piercing enough to be heard even over the noise. Through the forest marches the intimidating figure of Darth Vader, lightsaber in his hand.

"Get to the shuttle!", Leia shouts, firing shots at Vader, who casually reflects them with his saber.

<color="yellow"><color="red">Darth Vader</color> cannot suffer {H} and cannot be defeated.</color>

Many Imperial Assault missions need to be resolved in a certain amount of rounds. Some have hard time limits and end in a defeat when that limit is passed, others, like this tutorial, introduce complications after a certain amount of time.

eventActions.tbText: The Imperial forces appear to have regrouped. A man wearing the uniform of an officer appears between the trees, pointing at you. He is soon followed by another stormtrooper squad. "Get them!", he shouts. "Subdue them before Lord Vader arrives!"

<color="yellow">The Imperial Officer is an Elite group, and it has a modification: +3 Health. This means he has a Health of 8. This is displayed both in his thumbnail and in his activation window.</color>

At the end of each round, the Empire earns {D} (threat), a currency it can spend on deploying new groups and figures. Imperial Commander automatically decides if and what to deploy. It also indicates where to deploy them. The app can deploy new groups, but it can also reinforce existing groups. This means that it picks a group that has had some figures defeated and deploys more figures for that group. If that happens, place the new figures as close as possible to other figures of that group. From now on, {D} increases at the end of each round, and there may be more deployments.

In the new activation windows, you will notice a line called Reposition Target. The Reposition Target tells you where Imperial figures move when they reposition. The reposition target does not change how many movement points a figure gains, but it does override how far away from a Rebel it moves. Basically: The Imperial figures always try to fulfill the Reposition Target first, and the reposition distance given by the instruction second.

<color="yellow">The Stormtroopers, for example, try to block the Rebel's access to the shuttle by getting in the way. If they can do so while staying 4 spaces away from the Rebels, they do so. If they can block access to the shuttle, but need to be closer or further away from the Rebels, though, they will ignore the reposition "value" and focus on the target.

Don't sweat it too much, though. You should not pore over every single Imperial movement. If in doubt, just wing it, don't think too much about it.</color>

events.eventText:
The officer hastily gestures toward you, then dives for cover.

<color="yellow">The Imperial Officer's first instruction line is:</color>

{A} ORDER: Another Imperial figure with a figure cost of 6 or less that can perform an attack attacks (Rebel name).

<color="yellow">Imperial Officers prefer to let others do the fighting for them. When resolving ORDER, pick the figure with the highest figure cost (maximum 6) that can attack the selected Rebel. If no figure can attack the selected Rebel, pick the figure with the highest figure cost (maximum 6) that can attack any Rebel figure.</color>

eventActions.tbText:
<color="yellow">You can find the figure cost at the top left of a Deployment card. The number there is the deployment cost, so this is the amount of {D} the app has to spend to deploy the group.

If the group consists of only 1 figure, figure cost is equal to the deployment cost. Groups with multiple figures have a smaller number next to the deployment cost. This is the cost of an individual figure. The Stormtroopers, for example, have a deployment cost of 6 and a figure cost of 2.</color>

<color="yellow">Note that the instruction is preceded by a {A} icon, not a {Q} icon. ORDER is not an attack action, so the Imperial Officer can still spend an action on a {Q} instruction afterward.

Also note that the last instruction line is not preceded by a {A} or {Q} icon, so it does not cost an action. The Officer always resolves the last instruction line, if possible.</color>

buttonList.theText: Learn about how a campaign is structured
Learn about how to setup and play missions

events.eventText: An Imperial Assault campaign consists of multiple missions played one after the other. There are two types of missions: {-} Story Missions are campaign-specific missions that advance the campaign's story. {-} Side Missions are smaller missions that occur between story missions. They can be used to gain allies or other rewards. Playing a campaign is simple. Players first resolve a mission, and then have the opportunity to purchase new Item cards and Class cards. Then they resume their narrative by choosing and resolving a new mission. They continue resolving these stages until the campaign ends with a climactic mission known as a finale.

eventActions.tbText: A campaign always starts with the same mission, called Introduction. (For example, the core game campaign always starts with the mission "Aftermath".) To continue a campaign, players check the campaign log in the app and resolve the next available (unmarked) stage. The campaign log also tells you on what threat level the next mission is supposed to be played.

Here's how to choose which mission to play next: {-} Story Missions: After a story mission ends, Imperial Commander will tell the players what Story Mission cards to put into play. They are the active story missions. The next time the campaign log tells the players to play a story mission, they choose one of the active Story Mission cards to play, then discard all remaining Story Mission cards in play. Then they open Imperial Commander, select the mission to play, choose threat level, heroes, allies and villains, and play. {-} Side Missions: After the "Introduction" mission is resolved, the players shuffle the side mission deck and draw 2 side mission cards. They are the active side missions. When the campaign log tells the players to play a side mission, they choose one of the active side missions to play. After they resolve the side mission, they draw a new side mission card, so that there are always 2 side mission cards in play.

There are also missions called Imperial Missions. They are special side missions that can give a boost to the Empire. There are two types of Imperial missions. {-} Imperial side missions: They are put into play in addition to the two regular side missions. The players can choose to play the Imperial side mission instead of one of their regular side missions. When they choose to play another side mission while an Imperial side mission is available, discard the Imperial side mission. The Empire automatically gains the listed reward. {-} Forced missions: Some Imperial missions force players to resolve a specific mission. After one of these cards is put into play, players immediately resolve the listed mission and then discard the mission card. The campaign log tells you when to play an Imperial mission. Some mission entries in the log feature a red icon with a stylized planet on it. Whenever you have resolved that mission completely and have performed the Rebel Upgrade Stage, click the icon. The app then decides whether you draw an Imperial mission or not.
In the wiki documentation, you can find a specific example for campaign structure and progress. Just click the link on the start screen of Imperial Commander.

events.eventText: As players resolve missions and progress through the campaign, they resolve a series of steps after each played mission. After that, they refer to the campaign log to determine their next mission.

eventActions.tbText: Certain missions (usually side missions, but some story missions) give the heroes rewards for finishing them. {-} Reward Cards: Many rewards come in the form of reward cards that grant the heroes certain abilities. Most can be used as written. Some reward cards, however, need to be changed in Saga mode. A list can be found in the wiki documentation. {-} Allies: Green side missions reward the heroes with allies. Once the players have earned an ally, they can decide to bring them on any subsequent mission. Just select them in the mission setup screen. Bringing an ally, however, increases the threat the Empire gets at the beginning of a mission, so the players need to weigh risk versus reward of bringing allies. Earned allies stay earned for the entire campaign.

The Empire can also earn rewards. Imperial Commander will tell you what rewards the Empire gets, but they might differ from what is written in the campaign guide or on the Mission card, because many Imperial reward cards are not used in Imperial Commander. Here are the general rules: {-} Earned Villains: If the Imperial player gains a villain as a reward, set its card aside. Next time when playing a mission, select that villain as earned in the mission setup screen. Earned villains stay earned for the entire campaign. {-} Other Imperial Rewards: If the Imperial player would gain any other reward card, the Empire does not gain that reward card. Instead, increase the threat level of the next mission (and only the next mission) by 1. During the Rebel Upgrade stage, the Rebel players can decide to spend 50 credits per hero to prevent this. {-} Forced Missions: If the Rebel players lose a Forced Mission, increase the threat level of the next mission (and only the next mission) by 2. During the Rebel Upgrade stage, the Rebel players can decide to spend 100 credits per hero to prevent this. You don't need to keep all this in mind, the app is going to tell you what happens.

After a mission is resolved, the players can purchase new cards during the Rebel Upgrade Stage. They can first spend experience points to purchase new Class cards and can then spend credits to purchase new Item cards. In the app's campaign log, you can keep track of experience points and credits as well as any rewards, villains, or allies earned and any items purchased.

To purchase Class cards, each player looks at all cards in their hero's Class deck and can purchase any number of those cards.

{-} In order to purchase a Class card, the hero must spend a number of XP equal to the card's cost.
{-} Once purchased, the hero retains the cards for the remainder of the campaign.

Players can spend earned credits on Item cards. Item cards are divided into three tiers. Each tier has its own Item deck. Players should make note of the total number of cards in each Item deck at the start of the campaign. If playing with just the core game, the number is 12 for each deck.

The campaign log tells the players which Item cards are available after a mission is resolved. To purchase Item cards, the players shuffle the Item deck listed on the campaign log and draw a number of cards equal to half the starting size (rounded up). The players may purchase any number of those cards and return any unpurchased cards to the deck.

{-} If multiple Item decks are listed on the campaign log, players shuffle and draw cards from each deck.
{-} In order to purchase an Item card, the players must spend credits equal to the card's cost.
{-} After purchasing an Item card, players give the Item card to the hero of their choice. Items can be re-assigned at the start of each mission.
{-} Immediately before purchasing Item cards, the players can sell any of the Item cards they already own. Each sold card is returned to the game box. Then the heroes receive an amount of credits equal to the card's cost.
{-} Item cards without a credit cost can be sold for the heroes to receive 50 credits.
In the wiki documentation, you can find a specific example for campaign structure and progress. Just click the link on the start screen of Imperial Commander.

events.eventText: To play a mission, players perform a series of steps.

eventActions.tbText: Step 1: Select Mission Consult the campaign log to decide which mission to play next.
Step 2: Prepare Dice, Cards, and Other Tokens Place all dice, the Condition cards and Supply deck, damage tokens, strain tokens, and condition tokens within easy reach of all players.
Step 3: Gather heroes Gather all Hero sheets, Hero Class cards, Item cards, Reward cards, and any other cards in the heroes' possession.
Step 4: Start Mission Select New Game from the start screen. Select the mission, the heroes, the threat level, the difficulty, as well as any earned villains. Decide whether to bring an ally.

Step 5: Deploy Rebel figures Places all hero figures in the space indicated by the app or as close to it as possible. The players choose the order in which their figures are deployed. Before placing their figures, they choose the Item cards that they will bring to the mission. Each hero may bring up to 1 Armor ({R}), 2 Weapons, and 3 Equipment ({S}).
Step 6: Deploy Allies If the Rebel players chose to deploy an ally, deploy it as close as possible to the deployment space. Then the mission starts with the first Rebel activation.

After a mission is finished, players resolve the Post-Mission Cleanup: {-} Wounded heroes flip their hero sheets to the healthy side. Heroes recover all {H} (damage) and {C} (strain). {-} The players shuffle all of their Supply cards back into the Supply deck. {-} Heroes gain 50 credits for each crate token claimed during the mission and then discard the tokens. {-} Unless otherwise specified by abilities or rules, all other tokens are discarded. {-} Players return the Mission card corresponding to the mission that was just resolved to the game box. {-} If players just resolved the introductory mission, shuffle the Side Mission deck, draw two cards, and place them faceup on the table. {-} If players just resolved a regular (non-Imperial) Side Mission (drawn from the side mission deck), draw a random card from the Side Mission deck and place it faceup on the table. It is now an active mission. {-} If there is still an Imperial Mission card in play, resolve the instructions on it.
In the wiki documentation, you can find more about how to setup and play missions. Just click the link on the start screen of Imperial Commander.

events.eventText: May the Force be with you, and have fun with Imperial Commander!
When starting a new campaign in Imperial Commander, you need to perform a few steps.

eventActions.tbText: Step 1: Prepare Supply Place the dice, Condition cards, and the damage, strain, and condition tokens within easy reach of all players. Place the Reference cards within easy reach of all players. Remove the card "Troop Data" from the Supply card deck and return it to the game box. Then shuffle the Supply deck and place it facedown in reach of all players.

Step 2: Prepare Set-Aside Components Set aside the Deployment cards, gray figures, map tiles, doors, and the objective, terminal, and crate tokens. These components are called for at various times by the app - they should be neatly organized so they can be retrieved easily during play.

Step 3: Select heroes Each player selects a hero to play (at least two if playing single-player) and gathers the Hero sheet, figure, and Hero Class deck that correspond to that hero. Each player places his or her components in his or her play area. Each player retrieves the Item cards from his or her Hero Class deck that do not have an XP value in the lower-left corner, placing them faceup in his or her play area. For a two-hero game, each player also takes a “Legendary” Reward card. For a three-hero game, each player takes a “Heroic” Reward card. These Reward cards serve as a reminder about heroes’ bonus health and activations.

Step 4: Build Side Mission Deck Create the Side Mission deck that will be used during this campaign. Players first sort the Side Mission cards by the color on the face of the cards. Then they create the Side Mission deck by shuffling together the following cards: {-} 1. Each red Side Mission card (personal missions) corresponding to their heroes {-} 2. Four green cards (ally missions) of the players' choice {-} 3. Four random gray cards (general side missions)

Step 5: Build Imperial Mission Deck Gather all Side Mission and Forced Mission Agenda cards. Shuffle them together to form the Imperial mission deck. Cards will be drawn from this deck as described under "Learn about how a campaign is structured".

Step 6: Start Introduction Mission Start a new campaign in Imperial Commander. Choose the campaign you want to play and give it a name. Select the chosen heroes in the campaign overview, then click the green arrow next to the Introduction mission. Choose the difficulty level and start the mission.

Some campaigns require a slightly different setup. You can find more about this (and more details) in campaign guide or the respective campaign info (click the info icon in the campaign overview) or in the wiki documentation (click the link on the start screen of Imperial Commander).
